title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The material used is Binny stone. The architect was David Rhind, Esq, With the view of inspecting Donaldson's Hospital we must now retrace our steps to the west end of Princes Street, and proceed from that in a direct line west by Shandwick Place, Maitland Street, and the Haymarket.

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: From thishouse, on the evening of the 23d of February, 1827,he walked to the Assembly Rooms in George Street,near Hanover Street, and there, at a public dinner,he confessed for the first time in public the authorship of the " Waverley Novels." As Lockhart writes," The sensation produced by this scene was, in newspaper phrase, ' unprecedented.' "Between 1828 and 1830 Scott lived at No. 6Shandwick Place — now Maitland Street, a continuation of Princes Street. In February, 1831, whilesuperintending the making of his will, he was theguest of his bookseller, Robert Cadell, in AtholCrescent, and the last night he spent in Edinburghwas at the Douglas Hotel, 34 and 35 St. AndrewSquare, now the office of the Scottish Union andInsurance Company ; and on the morning of thenth of July, 1832, he was carried unconscious fromthis house and from Edinburgh, to die at Abbotsford two months later.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: November 6. I took possession of No. 6 Shandwick Place, Mrs. Jobson's house. Mr. Cadell had taken it for me ; terms 100 for four months cheap enough, as it is a capital house.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: At two o'clock went to bury poor George Burnet, the son of Gilbert Innes, in as heavy a rain as I ever saw. Was in Shandwick Place again by four and

title: Literary landmarks of Edinburgh,
author: Hutton, Laurence
snippet: Between 1828 and 1830 Scott lived at No. 6 Shandwick Place — now Maitland Street, a continuation  of Princes Street. In February, 1831, while superintending the making of his will, he was the guest of his bookseller, Robert Cadell, in Athol Crescent, and the last night he spent in Edinburgh was at the Douglas Hotel, 34 and 35 St. Andrew Square, now the office of the Scottish Union and Insurance Company; and on the morning of the iith of July, 1832, he was carried unconscious from this house and from Edinburgh, to die at Abbotsford  two months later.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: ' Lady Jane Stuart's house was No. 12 Maitland Street, opposite Shandwick Place. Mrs. Skene told Mr. Lockhart that at Sir Walter's first meeting with his old friend a very painful scene occurred, and she added "I think it highly probable that it was on returning from this call that he committed to writing the verses, To Time, by his early favourite.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The operation delayed us three hours, so it was seven o'clock before  we reached our dinner and a good fire in Shandwick Place, and we were wellnigh frozen to death. During this excursion I walked very ill with more pain, in fact, than I ever remember to have felt and, even leaning on John Lockhart, could hardly get on.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: In the meantime George Cheape and his son came in. We dined at half -past three, but it was seven ere we set off, and did not reach the house in Shandwick Place till eleven at night. Thus ended our Club for the year 1830, its thirteenth anniversary.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The operation delayed us three hours, so it was seven o'clock before we reached our dinner and a good fire in Shandwick Place, and we were wellnigh frozen to death. During this excursion I walked very ill with more pain, in fact, than I ever remember to have felt and, even leaning on John Lockhart, could hardly get on.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: At two o'clock went to bury poor George Burnet, the son of Gilbert Innes, in as heavy a rain as I ever saw. Was in Shandwick Place again by four and made these entries. I dine to-day with the Club ; grant Heaven it fair before  six o'clock !

author: Scott, Walter

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: \Shandwick Place,] January 15. Off we came, and despite of rheumatism I got through the journey comfortably.
